instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.CD3125: What is CD3125? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3125 was most likely referring to CD3215.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> misbehaving. Strange DCIN and other pulsing rails
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> i fixed around 18 months ago for minor liquid damage has come back to me.
I originally fixed the board by running pin 2 <RESISTOR>R4911</RESISTOR> to Debug power button, at the time of doing this no schematics were available and pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R4911</RESISTOR> was completely destroyed, so running to the debug power pads was the only option i had.

It has worked well since the above repair until now. Now it works however its not behaving like it should! When the charger is plugged in, sometimes DCIN pulses between 5V and 20V, this seems inconsistent, sometimes it will work for hours, sometimes it wont post.

When running of the battery with a charger plugged in it behaves normally for a few hours and then goes into some sort of quarter fan spin pulse. Originally i suspected an issue with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s however it seems to still be going into a quarter fan spin cycle with the charger unplugged. With the charger unplugged G3H remains constant and so does battery voltage, but everything S5 and beyond seems to pulse.

I can recreate this fault without fail by trying to do a clean install on the device. 
Does anyone know if when a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> fails if the machine will run normally off the battery?
One thing ive noticed is that the battery cycles have not increase since the original repair around 18 months ago, suggesting it has been ran on its charger for almost its entire lifetime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> misbehaving. Strange DCIN and other pulsing rails
threads.message: If any <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> fails, the machine won't power on. Was their liquid possibly near the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> by chance?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> misbehaving. Strange DCIN and other pulsing rails
threads.message:
When you get it working, does it recognize the battery?
Does it always start in SMC bypass mode?

Check exact value for <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and <RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR>/62.
Post voltage for <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> when MLB doesn't start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> misbehaving. Strange DCIN and other pulsing rails
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 44540"]If any <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> fails, the machine won't power on. Was their liquid possibly near the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> by chance?[/QUOTE]

Nope, liquid was very localised to <RESISTOR>R4911</RESISTOR> and the surrounding area, and extremely minor. You can only tell its ever been damaged if you really look hard for it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> misbehaving. Strange DCIN and other pulsing rails
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44541"]When you get it working, does it recognize the battery?
Does it always start in SMC bypass mode?

Check exact value for <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and <RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR>/62.
Post voltage for <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> when MLB doesn't start.[/QUOTE]

When it is running it is recognising and charging the battery.
It does starts normally (not in SMC bypass). Since the original repair i have removed my wire from debug power button and replaced <RESISTOR>R4911</RESISTOR> wiring it to the correct net, so this board can now be treated as unmodified.

I will check exact value of the resistors, and the voltages tomorrow when i am back in work.
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> misbehaving. Strange DCIN and other pulsing rails
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and <RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR>/62 All measure perfectly (1ohm) each
I have been able to get it into its failure mode. When this happens all power rails other than CPU-Vcore pulse. I belive it is caused by some USB C charging issue maybe. This is because in its failure state DCIN seems to be wrong (pulsing 1.7V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>). If i reseat the charger it seems to start working again.

<SIGNAL>SMC_BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> remains 0V (batt plugged in)
<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> pulses to around 0.3V.
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> misbehaving. Strange DCIN and other pulsing rails
threads.message:
Replaced all 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s with no improvement.
I am confused because something is causing the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s to not communicate with the charger during its failed state. 
Because <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is not pulsing it leads me to believe a GPIO pin is causing the DCIN Rail to pulse. 

Does anyone know of all the requirements for the DCIN rail to come high?. As i understand the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s need to be present and communicate with there ROM chip via i2c, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is needed to power the <CHIP>CD3125</CHIP>'s, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> is required from <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> to power the ROM chip. CC1 and CC2 select voltage from the charger.ect

I am really confused by the DCIN rail pulsing, maybe a Reset signal is pulsing causing this?
Any help would be awesome.
